item.title: 20 prerequisites for Quantum Mechanics (Non-relativistic)
item.description: Fluid mechanics Group theory Heat transfer, thermodynamics, and fluid mechanics Linear algebra 101 Newtonian mechanics (you do NOT know it sucker, talk to me if you wanna challenge) Special relativistic mechanics Electrodynamics Action in the relativistic mechanics, Action principle in classical mechanics (okay only basics) Lagrangians in Relativistic, Non relativistic mechanics, do a bit Lagrangian mechanics Hamiltonian mechanics (super freaking important) Now bit of play around, do cool casual stuff like Electric circuitry, Electronics, digital stuff, etc etc metric spaces, limits of functions between metric spaces Function spaces, l₁, l₂, L₂,…etc, basics is fine, understand the vector space+inner product structure ~ ODEs/PDEs (shouldn’t have said 20 pre requisites dyam) how to make khichdi… and usual foods (you’ll know if you were in PHY101 group xD) Topology: connected spaces, simply connected spaces// parallelisable, and another term I’m forgetting… Dynamical systems, Hamiltonian system as a dynamical system, Chaos in dynamical systems, Chaos in Non Relativistic mechanics~ the fun stuff!

item.title: Ted Shifrin’s Linear algebra and Multivariable calculus
item.description: parent:: [[notes/academic-recommendations]] This fairly rigorous but very entertaining set of lectures (where the instructor uses blackboard!) explains all the stuff in Multivariable calculus one encounters during the core years of a Fundamental Sciences programme: multiple derivatives, volumous integrals, change of coordinates, and especially does everything in a proper linear algebraic setting (which becomes very important in the long run) and with lots of examples and pictures!
